context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And we are asking you to tell us what the evil is in the speech that nonprofit corporations present in election campaigns.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And all of the comments you have made so far would equally support the proposition that you can prohibit the publication of their monthly newspaper, or prohibit them from giving to churches, as Justice Scalia suggested, or that you can require them to give to one party and not to the other.

context.speaker: Louis J. Caruso
context.text: I don't know of anything like that being in the Campaign Finance Act.

context.speaker: Louis J. Caruso
context.text: Here again I say that the evil is that they are... they have members, people involved in corporations, they give money to corporations, they invest money in corporations, not for the purposes of becoming involved in the political process.

context.text: Mr. Winterhalter, let's go back to that second clause of 7501 that Justice O'Connor referred to.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The amount of tax so collected or withheld shall be held to be a special fund in trust for the United States.

context.speaker: Paul R. Gettleman
context.text: In this particular case the sentencer is precluded from making the determination that death is an appropriate sentence in this case.

context.speaker: Paul R. Gettleman
context.text: Once the aggravating circumstance is found and no mitigation is found, then he has no say in it.

context.speaker: Paul R. Gettleman
context.text: It is a type of mechanical, rigid process that the Court suggested was inappropriate.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I guess I am just repeating what Justice Kennedy suggested, but you're... you're... you're sounding like the opposition in Furman.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Wasn't Furman directed exactly against leaving it up to the jury whether in a broad category of cases you want to impose the death sentence?

context.speaker: Paul R. Gettleman
context.text: But the... but... Justice Scalia--

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: And that's not a step that should be treated lightly.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: So, in this particular case, the... the function of aggravating is to narrow the class of death eligibles.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: And that... that's... that's good facet of Pennsylvania's statute, because it helps to reduce arbitrariness.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, in answer to Justice Stevens' question, I... I assume that if the state were trying to show there were no mitigating circumstances, it could introduce much of this evidence, I... i.e., to show that he was not acting under extreme emotional or mental disturbance when he went back and... and told his accomplices in the car that he was going to kill the victim, and... and then discussed it with the victim for a while.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I assume that is all relevant to show that there is no mitigating circumstance.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: It... it... Justice Kennedy, that is correct.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: And those reviews take considerable amount of time.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: And I think it is important that our Supreme Court gives consideration to these cases so carefully.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: It requires the Supreme Court to review the verdict, to determine whether it is a verdict that is not based on passion or prejudice, or some other arbitrary factor.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Of course there are those, I think Mr. Justice Powell among others, who have said if you are going to have a death penalty you ought to enforce it.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: You have on death row the number of people equal to half of those in this room.

context.speaker: Ernest D. Preate, Jr.
context.text: There's those... there are those who will agree with that argument.

context.text: The Eight Amendment imposes no further requirement that the jury be left totally free to find in favor of a life sentence even though it found aggravating circumstances but no mitigating ones.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Are you abandoning your duty of fair representation claim?

context.speaker: Francis J. Landry
context.text: --No, we are not abandoning it.

context.speaker: Francis J. Landry
context.text: We're... I'm trying to--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But are you agreeing with Justice Scalia that it just doesn't apply in a case like this?

context.speaker: Francis J. Landry
context.text: --We believe it does apply in a case like this, because this contract, or this out-of-work referral system, was established by the collective bargaining agreement, where and in the collective bargaining agreement, Article 5 of that agreement, places a duty upon the... places a contractual obligation on the union to furnish workers upon request by the employer.

context.text: And the employer, if he... can submit letters of request to the union, and after 48 hours period, if the union is unable to furnish sufficient workers in order to fulfill the employer's need, then the... at that point, the employer can go out and fill his needs with other--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: --you say--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Then... then you give up a certain element of certainty in the due process standard of Pennoyer that Justice Scalia referred to in his question to you... to your opponent, that every... in... every jurisdictional inquiry is going to be kind of an ad hoc fact-specific one, isn't it?

context.speaker: James O. Devereaux
context.text: --Well, I think that, as the Court pointed out most recently in 1984 in Burger King, the physical presence of the defendant in the state can in fact enhance the affiliation of the defendant with that state and can enhance the foreseeability of being sued in that state.

context.speaker: James O. Devereaux
context.text: And I don't see anything inherently unfair about pinning jurisdiction on the fact that the defendant in this day and age where people do in fact travel across state borders regularly is found within the state and therefore is... is subject to the jurisdiction of that state.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Can you give me a hypothetical in which the witness' description of his own testimony would imperil, after the grand jury investigation is over, would imperil the... would be contrary to the policy of the statute?

context.speaker: George L. Waas
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, for this reason.

context.speaker: George L. Waas
context.text: As I said earlier--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Stevens asked you to give him a hypothetical.

context.speaker: George L. Waas
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: George L. Waas
context.text: Let us assume that in the course of his representation the grand jury were to ask, with respect to a confidential informant whose name, if disclosed, would implicate that confidential informant to the point of risking his life.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We granted certiorari to review this judgment and for reasons stated in an opinion filed with the Clerk, we agree with the Court of Appeals that Florida’s interest in prohibiting a grand jury witness from disclosing his own testimony after an investigation has ended are insufficient to overcome Smith’s First Amendment right to make a truthful statement of information he acquired outside the grand jury room.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.text: The question it presents is as follows: In determining whether there is diversity of citizenship between the parties as is required for federal diversity jurisdiction, complete diversity is required, that is, all the plaintiffs must be citizens of different states from all the defendants.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This is not to say that Oregon may not, if it wishes, exempt the religious use of peyote from its criminal prohibition.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It assuredly may.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: A number of other states have done so, but to say that it may is not to say that it must.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We reaffirm today what Justice Frankfurter wrote for the Court in 1940 “conscientious scruples have not in the course of the long struggle for religious toleration relieved the individual from obedience to a general law not aimed at the promotion or restriction of religious beliefs.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The mere possession of religious convictions which contradict the relevant concerns of political society does not relieve the citizen from the discharge of political responsibilities."

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In this case, the respondents are a group of lawyers who represent indigent criminal defendants in the District of Columbia.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: During a part of 1983, they agreed to refuse further clients until the district increase their fees.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The district eventually capitulated to their demand, and the Federal Trade Commission initiated an enforcement proceeding, and after a hearing found that the lawyers’ conduct was a per se violation of the antitrust laws.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Court of Appeals vacated the Commission’s order but in an opinion authored by Justice Stevens, we hold that the First Amendment does not insulate respondents’ conduct from an application of per se antitrust analysis.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The expressive component of this boycott does not adequately distinguish it from other price-fixing agreements subject to those rules.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We accordingly vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand for further proceedings.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We do not agree with the Florida Court’s conclusion however, that to comport with the Fourth Amendment, a policy of procedure governing inventory searches must require that either all containers or no containers be opened.

context.text: While such policies would be permissible, it would be equally permissible for an inventory search policy to allow police officials to open any containers whose contents they are unable to figure out from looking at the exterior of the container.

context.text: This is not a case where--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, what... what you are now saying gives me cause to wonder whether your response to Justice Kennedy was correct earlier.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought we had established that it... under the... under the indictment here it was clear that the state was going to use as a principal part of its case the... the intoxication.

context.speaker: Bridget R. Steller
context.text: --Your Honor, that would be some of the evidence introduced at this trial.

context.speaker: Bridget R. Steller
context.text: Obviously, the speed at which the defendant was traveling would not be relevant on his failure to keep right charge.

context.speaker: Bridget R. Steller
context.text: So there are different elements as you analyze the statutory elements, and some evidence, which is indicated in the bill of particulars, would not be included, just as the defendant's blood alcohol level would not be relevant at a failure to keep right trial.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But... but we have to evaluate your legal theory on the basis of what results it could produce, not just the results it might happen to produce in this case.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And you acknowledge that... that your legal theory can produce the result that Justice Stevens described.

context.speaker: Bridget R. Steller
context.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Bridget R. Steller
context.text: I would suggest to you that in the... you have indicated that society has an interest in law enforcement, and in enacting 1800(d) of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, the New York State legislature had a right to consider how the vehicle and traffic laws were to be enforced and how they would affect society.

context.text: A constructive trust remedy is prohibited unless some exception to the general statutory ban is applicable.

context.text: It is also inappropriate, we feel, to approve any generalized equitable exception to ERISA’s anti-alienation provision.

context.text: So, we think that there is nothing to recommend an approach that would make that requirement, if not meaningless, less important and perhaps trivial.

context.text: Mr. Martin, may I go back to Justice White's concern earlier that the language is plain as to the duty not to commence the action, but that the statute is silent as to the remedy for violating that duty.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you think in this case an action was commenced?

context.speaker: Brian J. Martin
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Nothing in the language, structure, or legislative history of the statute permits us to disregard its plain meaning or to allow equitable modification of the statutory requirement.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Accordingly, if a party fails to comply with the 60-day notice requirement, the District Court must dismiss the action as barred by the terms of the statute.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly affirmed.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion with which Justice Brennan joins.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Nothing in the language, structure, or legislative history of the statute permits us to disregard its plain meaning or to allow equitable modification of the statutory requirement.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.speaker: John R. Tunheim
context.text: I submit that the legislature could reasonably insist that both parents be notified, and reasonably believe that a two-parent notice system would serve the significant state interests that are inherent in a parental notification law and maximize the benefits that--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I stop you there with one question?

context.speaker: John R. Tunheim
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Going back to your dialogue with Justice Scalia earlier, just focusing simply on the parental interest in knowing what's happening to the child as one of the justifications for the two-parent requirement, does Minnesota vindicate that interest in any other statute?

context.speaker: John R. Tunheim
context.text: Justice Stevens, there are other statutes which require notice to both parents, a statute that requires notice to both parents when a minor seeks a name change, so there's one instance of an indication in which notice is required to both parents.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: How about Minnesota as compared to Ohio, in the area of drug treatment, sexually transmitted diseases and things of that character?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: There's a concern that the parents might object to the treatment, is that it?

context.speaker: John R. Tunheim
context.text: The concern that by notifying parents that a minor is undergoing drug abuse treatment, that that might keep a minor from coming in to get treatment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: From many medical procedures in general... and perhaps this is what you've been over with Justice Blackmun... I understand you to say that in Minnesota the requirement is not simply notification on the part of a minor, but consent of one parent?

context.speaker: John R. Tunheim
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John R. Tunheim
context.text: But in following up with Justice Stevens' question, I submit that the abortion situation is different and states are entitled to treat abortion differently.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: But that does not make them necessary parties to the action.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, if they had information sufficient so that a discovery order were issued requiring the... the employer to divulge the names and addresses of all the affected employees, and if that is a given, in other words, would the court not then have power to condition the discovery request on the transmission of notice that the court approved?

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: Justice, we submit that there is nothing in the rules which would provide for disclosure for this purpose, and the purpose was expressly--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: No, no, I am assuming, because Mr. Justice Brennan asked you if these other parties might not have some information, I am assuming that in a case, a court would find that the names and addresses of all the affected employees are discoverable.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: --Your Honor--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Could the court then, as a condition to its discovery order, impose restrictions setting forth the kinds of statements that should be made to the employees if a mailing went out?

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: We have... in this particular case, of course, there was no request to the court below for the discovery of names and addresses for any purpose other than to solicit.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: The court's decision below was based solely on its perception of its power to aid the Plaintiffs to go out to bring in all of the non parties before the court.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: That is the objection which we have, not to what discovery might be required at a subsequent date by the court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I think Justice Kennedy's question is perhaps directed to the at least implication of your statement that solicitation is a bad word.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: Oh, no.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: Judge... Justice, we have never objected to the solicitation by the Plaintiffs of non parties.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, the statute might run, I suppose.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: Your Honor, that can happen with respect to any potential litigant who might have a claim out there.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: And we have never, I don't think it has ever been suggested that it is the role of the judiciary to go out and to ensure that those who have statutes of limitation which might be running are brought in before the court so that the court can adjudicate their claims in a timely fashion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But Justice Stevens is right, it does... does it have anything to do with neutrality?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Is neutrality the problem or is it perhaps that there is no case or controversy.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Is that what you are saying?

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: Oh, I think so, Justice.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: I... I take comfort in the ability of the district courts to enter protective orders when necessary to--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But how could you enter protective orders saying you can't solicit these people as clients?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: They have got a First Amendment... as Justice Kennedy pointed out, they've got a First Amendment right to do that, no matter how they get the names.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: --It is customary in the age cases which the courts, the district courts adjudicate, for example, for them to set cut-off dates for opt-ins.

context.speaker: John A. Ridley
context.text: Typically, those cut off dates are not long after the filing of the initial complaint.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: You want me to believe that?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Leonard N. Flamm
context.text: I, I thought we chose the path that we were obliged to take in terms of best representing the class.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Why didn't you just, as Justice White said, just ask for another list?

context.speaker: Leonard N. Flamm
context.text: Because the solicitation issue hadn't been as clear with Shapero not yet decided.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: It was clearer than what you have now, isn't... wasn't it?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I guess not, on your thesis.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: He would be barred from using peremptory challenges to remove otherwise qualified jurors, black jurors, on the false assumption that because of their race they're not qualified to serve.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, how does that give you a fair cross-section jury if... if... Justice White's hypothesis is that out of 12 there are 12 blacks?

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: If the... if the prosecutor is allowed to use his peremptory challenges simply on the basis of his false assumptions and his biases, it is a severe injury to the selection process.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: And that is the key to--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What principle could you recommend to us or propose that allows us to say that only blacks are protected by the fair cross-section requirement?

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: --It would be based on this Court's recognition that the removal of blacks by peremptory challenge suggests that prosecutors are misusing the challenges to remove on grounds of race.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: There has been--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, that gets back to Justice White's original question, that this isn't the fair cross-section argument you're making at all.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's simply an equal protection argument.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: --The argument has elements of equal protection analysis to it because there is the concern for the excluded jurors.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: So, the issue of a denial of equal protection has been presented because blacks are being removed on grounds of race.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: But we've presented as a remedy, a Sixth Amendment contention because that harms the jury selection system which the defendant does have standing to raise.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: So, the difficulty also, of course, is that this Court decided Batson--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The standing issue is really quite interesting because, as Justice White points out, Batson wasn't a member of the class that was at issue in the case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He happened to be of the same race, but the class was prospective jurors.

context.speaker: Donald S. Honchell
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 88-5050, Holland against Illinois will be announced by Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This case is here on petition for certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois which upheld the petitioner’s conviction of aggravated kidnapping, rape, deviant sexual assault, and armed robbery.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The preliminary question it presents is whether a white criminal defendant has standing to contest the preemptory challenge of blacks from his jury as a violation of the Sixth Amendment.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Nor do we hold that this white defendant does not have a valid constitutional challenge to such racial exclusion of blacks under the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: All that we do hold is that he does not have a valid constitutional challenge based on the Sixth Amendment.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The judgment of the Illinois Supreme Court is therefore affirmed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion; Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Brennan and Blackmun have joined; Justice Stevens has also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Nor do we hold that this white defendant does not have a valid constitutional challenge to such racial exclusion of blacks under the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: In the case of automobiles, that's correct.

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: And if you say a stolen automobile, there you have no possessory interest.

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: A person has no possessory interest in a stolen object.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, take Justice Scalia's example but make it lawn furniture in the back yard or in plain... in plain view of somebody's front lawn some furniture, and an officer has probable cause to believe it's stolen, as in this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you think the officer could go on without a warrant and just--

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: Your Honor, again, in that--

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: Again, in that situation, there is no possessory interest in stolen objects.

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: So there's no interest to protect there whatsoever.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, there's... there's probable cause to believe there's no interest to protect, but it hasn't been resolved by any judicial authority that that's the fact.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You... you agree with Justice Scalia?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You just walk on the premises and help yourself to--

context.speaker: Juliana Drous
context.text: No, I do not.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: The state jurisdiction--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Your reason for saying this is not discrimination against the Federal cause of action is because you say comparable claims in the state court would also be dismissed?

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Is... is the case you refer to in your colloquy with Justice Stevens, Schmauss against Snoll, is that cited in your brief?

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And that you regard as the strongest case from the district court of appeal on this question of jurisdictional?

Howlett By and Through Howlett v. Rose.speaker: Justice Stevens

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: That is absolutely... is absolutely right.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: I mean, our position... I mean, the question in this case, of course, is whether the state has to entertain the claim in the first instance.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: And if it does not entertain analogous state law claims, as it does not, we think it shouldn't... it isn't... under no Federal obligation, constitutional or statutory, to entertain the claim here.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I'm still not quite clear on why the jurisdictional argument makes a difference from Justice Scalia's example of, say, a $10,000 ceiling on recovery.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That would be equally nondiscriminatory.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Now, why would one raise a different Federal question than the other?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, do you think that trickery can ever amount to coercion?

context.speaker: Marcia L. Friedl
context.text: There could be situations where trickery amounts to coercion.

context.speaker: Marcia L. Friedl
context.text: My point is that in your normal everyday undercover situation the deception itself is going to actually take away the coercion that... that the police domination type coercion that Miranda was concerned with.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, did you... I would have answered that question from Justice O'Connor perhaps a little differently.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do you think trickery is a subspecies of coercion?

context.speaker: Marcia L. Friedl
context.text: There... trickery can constitute... it would be trick and not merely trickery.

context.speaker: Joseph Claps
context.text: --The warrant requirement.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --of the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Joseph Claps
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Which, as you pointed out with Justice Scalia, is a very different question from whether it's a Leon-type exception from the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Joseph Claps
context.text: In the cert. petition.

context.speaker: Joseph Claps
context.text: But in our brief--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 88-6075, James versus Illinois will be announced by Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The impeachment exception to the exclusionary rule have permits the prosecution in a criminal proceeding to introduce evidence illegally obtained from the defendant to impeach the defendant’s own testimony if he takes the stand.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that this extension is inconsistent with a balance of values underlying our previous applications of the exclusionary rule expansion of the exceptions would significantly weaken the exclusionary rules to deter effect and police misconduct by enhancing the expected value to the prosecution of an illegally obtained evidence by deterring defendants from calling witnesses in the first place and thereby keeping exculpatory evidence from the jury.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: When police officers confront opportunities to obtain illegal evidence, excluding such evidence from only the prosecution’s case in chief, would lead officer with little to lose and much to gain by overstepping the constitutional limits on evidence gathered.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Illinois Supreme Court is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with our opinion filed this day with the Clerk.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a concurring opinion; Justice Kennedy filed a dissenting opinion in which the Chief Justice and Justices O’Connor and Scalia have joined.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Greenan
context.text: And that is what Judge Posner, in the Panhandle Eastern case, said was a lost profits damage that was for sales that were not made, has nothing to do with the overcharge for the sales that were made and were passed on.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Oh, I... I agree with that.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Greenan
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But it does not demonstrate... you answered Justice O'Connor by saying that the Illinois Brick theory was if you can be sure that the intermediate purchaser has not been harmed it's... it's okay to apply Illinois Brick.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But we can't be sure that the intermediate purchaser here has not been harmed, can we?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Greenan
context.text: I don't believe that Illinois Brick says that you can be sure that the intermediate purchaser not be harmed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't either.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Greenan

context.speaker: Thomas J. Greenan
context.text: In that instance it is easy to demonstrate that the utility did not absorb the overcharge.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But even in the residential consumer, as Justice O'Connor pointed out, there are some people who turn the thermostat down and have to buy an extra sweater.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Greenan
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And there is no way they can recover for that sweater.

context.speaker: Seth M. Hufstedler
context.text: Now, if the State Bar said... or, if the state said, we're going to pass a statute and you're going to go out and pick one side of every issue and then go out and campaign only for that side, I would have serious doubts that that was a legitimate public issue and would pass original constitutional muster for a legitimate government purpose.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yet the governor of California may go from place to place in the state and take positions on just one side of issues and certainly no one can challenge the fact that the state may be paying for his trips.

context.speaker: Seth M. Hufstedler
context.text: Absolutely certain that elected officials can do so and can endorse any issue they wish to do so, and that's paid for by taxes and you can't demit, you can't refuse to pay taxes or get part of it back because somebody did.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In Justice Scalia's hypothetical with this do-good agency that can lobby on any issue, could only the lawyers be compelled to pay dues to that to support its activities?

context.speaker: Seth M. Hufstedler
context.text: Well, I would suppose it would have to have a fairly close relationship to lawyers.

context.speaker: Seth M. Hufstedler
context.text: But I have no doubt that without being confiscatory the state can impose a tax upon lawyers for the right to practice law and then use those funds however it sees fit for any legitimate purpose.

Keller v. State Bar of California.case_name: Keller v. State Bar of California

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Anthony T. Caso
context.text: It's the way California defined them, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Anthony T. Caso
context.text: And let me give you an example.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: --In line with Justice Stevens, we have to say... you want us to say something specific, don't you?

context.speaker: Anthony T. Caso
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: What do you want us to say specifically?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But at the time they did not have the right to protect their regional banking scheme from, from ISBs.

context.speaker: Arthur E. Wilmarth, Jr.
context.text: Well, that, that of course was in 1984, and it is our view that the Commerce Clause did not prevent them from taking a non-discriminatory step toward withdrawing the option from everyone.

context.speaker: Arthur E. Wilmarth, Jr.
context.text: That that is really equivalent, I think, to what the Maryland legislature did in Exxon Corp. versus Governor of Maryland, or in a sense what Minnesota Clo--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, that, that may be a valid argument, but it seems to me it doesn't respond to Justice Kennedy's point, that the motivation was perfectly okay.

context.speaker: Arthur E. Wilmarth, Jr.
context.text: --Well--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're, you're... because the motivation wasn't perfectly okay if they did not have a right to preserve their regional, their regional system, against a particular type of bank.

context.speaker: Andrew L. Gordon
context.text: The mootness issue here obviously is essential to our case.

context.speaker: Andrew L. Gordon
context.text: And if there are any questions regarding the nature of Continental's intentions, you know, I would be happy and be pleased to expand on what I have just said.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: There have been questions on this for a long time.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I share Justice Stevens' perplexity.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This mootness issue didn't just pop up yesterday.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It has been here for a long time, and it would have been very easy to have some clear assurance in the record that the bank is serious about going into business here, of course subject to, you know, inter... subsequent change in economic conditions.

context.speaker: Gerald R. Grant
context.text: It's not included therein.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I know.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But he's a Respondent.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Why can't he defend the judgment, as Justice Blackmun asks?

context.speaker: Gerald R. Grant
context.text: My second response would be... and the name of the case doesn't jump to my mind at the moment, but it's cited in the answering brief... essentially Respondent's position is that he can defend the judgment below on any grounds available to him.

context.speaker: Gerald R. Grant
context.text: The logic of that would... would to me mean that he can defend it on any of the sentencing attacks that he made below, which were decided against him, and even those which were not decided.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The particular claim that's asserted in this case covers the hundreds of land orders throughout the West, and yet this particular Plaintiff has shown, we think, standing as to none but, at most, standing as to the particular injury claimed in the affidavits.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Now the court of appeals' decision in this regard giving the Federation nationwide standing based on one injury to a particular plaintiff under one land order raises the most serious separation of powers concerns because it aggregates in the district court all of the Bureau of Land Management orders since 1981, even though before that district court is one plaintiff complaining of one order.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Those types of separation of powers concerns are precisely what the standing doctrine is designed to avoid.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Turning briefly to the question of the supplemental affidavits, I'd first point out as I mentioned in response to Justice Stevens that those would certainly not end the case even if they were... should have been admitted because they go, again, only to particular plaintiffs' particular land orders.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: If the Court disagrees with us on those and if, in fact, the supplemental affidavits establish standing, it would only be to the limited parcels, the limited orders mentioned in those affidavits.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Now, the district court did not abuse its discretion in declining to admit these affidavits more than one month after the deadline set in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56(c) and in violation of the court order.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: All she says is that she is in the vicinity of the 150,000 acres, and you're telling me that the government has acknowledged that somewhere on 4,400 acres in those 156,000, all of which she may not have been near, there has been an adverse impact.

context.speaker: E. Barrett Prettyman, Jr.
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: E. Barrett Prettyman, Jr.
context.text: I'm saying that the government is talking about the exact area that she's talking about.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, I thought... go ahead and finish your answer to Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: E. Barrett Prettyman, Jr.
context.text: The government is talking about the harm that will come to aesthetics and wildlife from the opening of the mining and where the opening of the... opening to mining occurred was in the 4,455 which she says she's in the vicinity of.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It doesn't say she's in the vicinity of the 4,400 acres.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --I agree you can look at the Federal Register and see there--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Is there a map in these papers, or not?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --There are a variety of maps in... in--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, can we tell there's... can we get the answer to Justice Stevens' question looking at these maps?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --You have to know how to read the Federal Register notice.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It's done by the township and--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinions of the Court in two cases will be announced by Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the first case, Lytle versus Household Manufacturing Company and in an opinion filed with the Clerk, we hold that the District Court’s resolutions of the issue in the acts of a claim does not bar relitigation before a jury of the same issue and a legal claim.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We, therefore, reverse the judgment of the Fourth Circuit and remand for proceedings consistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinions of the Court in two cases will be announced by Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the first case, Lytle versus Household Manufacturing Company and in an opinion filed with the Clerk, we hold that the District Court’s resolutions of the issue in the acts of a claim does not bar relitigation before a jury of the same issue and a legal claim.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary.speaker: Justice Scalia
Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary.case_name: Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary Steel, Inc.
Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 16, 1990

context.speaker: Thomas W. Merrill
context.text: --No, we are going--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --is what they have said in effect.

context.speaker: Thomas W. Merrill
context.text: --We are going to declare it an unreasonable practice for the carrier to obtain a windfall, essentially, based on its own violation of the statute.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But in answering Justice O'Connor, you... you... you spoke as though the only obligation of the carrier is to file the tariff rate.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It is not.

context.speaker: Thomas W. Merrill
context.text: No, there is--

Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary.speaker: Justice Scalia
Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary.case_name: Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary Steel, Inc.
Maislin Industries, US, Inc. v. Primary.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 16, 1990

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, then let's charge and collect that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And... and what the Commission said--

context.speaker: Thomas W. Merrill
context.text: And the carrier violated that provision.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --What the Commission said, as Justice O'Connor pointed out, is that complying with that is an unreasonable billing practice.

context.speaker: Thomas W. Merrill
context.text: No, the Commission has not said that simply not collecting the tariff rate is an unreasonable billing practice.

context.speaker: Thomas W. Merrill
context.text: What the Commission has said is that when these four elements are identified... negotiation of the rate; reliance by the shipper on the carrier's compliance with all statutory requirements; nevertheless the carrier goes ahead and charges and collects the negotiated rate, not the tariff rate, over a long period of time typically; and finally, many years later, typically when the carrier is bankrupt, comes back and attempts to collect the much higher tariff rate... that that course of conduct, taken together, is an unreasonable practice.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: General Curran, can I ask you a question about the Maryland statute?

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If the, as Justice O'Connor pointed out in her question, the test seems to be whether the child could testify in the courtroom rather than in the presence of the defendant, and if there were a finding that the child could not testify in the courtroom and had to testify in a... over TV, and if the defendant had represented herself rather than having counsel, would the proceeding have gone forward in the... by television with the defendant confronting the child and doing the cross-examination herself?

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: Our statute does not permit that, Your Honor.

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: If the defendant chose to represent herself, then we could not use Section 9102, and that's... that's spelled out in the statute.

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: Read that... they were in fear for their lives, the lives of their parents.

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: They were told never to tell, and when you tell this to a person who is four years of age and five years of age, that makes an indelible imprint and thus we believe there is a difference.

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: Now, if--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, General Curran, I suppose it's possible that a rape victim, as Justice Scalia mentions, or even a victim of some Mafia-type crime, and an adult, could be so terrified to testify that it would be... perhaps the same finding could be made.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Would you think a state could, under those circumstances, adopt a similar rule?

context.speaker: J. Joseph Curran, Jr.
context.text: --Justice O'Connor, we don't--

context.speaker: William H. Murphy, Jr.
context.text: Absolutely not.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: So the judge wouldn't be able to observe what exactly or how the prosecutor was behaving?

context.speaker: William H. Murphy, Jr.
context.text: That is correct, nor would the jury, nor would co-counsel sitting next to Ms. Craig, nor would Ms. Craig.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: How... how under that procedure would the judge rule on an objection such as Justice O'Connor has suggested?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Say he objected to nodding his head.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: What would... how would the judge rule on it?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So... so that it cannot be considered by the jury as a mitigating factor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let's just get this very clear.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In Justice O'Connor's hypothetical there are three different possible mitigating factors that the jury discusses.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Each one has one juror object to it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: As of that point a conscientious jury, following the laws of North Carolina, cannot consider any one of those as a mitigating factor under North Carolina law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: As of that point a conscientious jury, following the laws of North Carolina, cannot consider any one of those as a mitigating factor under North Carolina law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Correct?

context.speaker: Joan Herre Byers
context.text: --That is correct, because, again, there was full consideration of the evidence which supports these factors, and if the defendant has not carried his burden of proving these factors to this jury, then it ought not use them in the balancing against those aggravating factors which--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The problem with that is, it seems to me, is there really, as Justice Stevens' earlier question pointed out, two aspects to mitigation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: One is, did the historical fact exist.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Was he drunk?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Hunter, do you have rebuttal?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You have five minutes remaining.

context.speaker: Malcolm Ray Hunter, Jr.
context.text: Thank you very much, Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Counsel, with reference to Justice White's last question, North Carolina has never contended, has it, that there must be unanimity only as to the historical fact, but that thereafter jurors can weigh or weigh... not weigh on an individual basis.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They've never contended that, have they?

context.speaker: Malcolm Ray Hunter, Jr.
context.text: No, Your Honor.

Metro Broadcasting, Inc. v. Federal Comm.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Metro Broadcasting, Inc. v. Federal Comm.case_name: Metro Broadcasting, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission
Metro Broadcasting, Inc. v. Federal Comm.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 1990

context.speaker: Harry F. Cole
context.text: I believe you understood my point precisely, that... that I'm not arguing that these factors can be taken into account.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You're saying that the government cannot take those factors into account?

context.speaker: Harry F. Cole
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, supposing that there's... that there's... take a community in the southwest and take Justice Scalia's hypothesis where there's an actual survey that... and it happens to be largely Hispanic, that there are 100,000 people there, 80,000 of them prefer mariachi bands and there's no station providing mariachi bands.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Can't the FCC make some requirement that the station provide mariachi bands?

context.speaker: Harry F. Cole
context.text: I suppose it could, but what it can't do is compel that the license which is issued by the FCC go to a Hispanic or Mexican or what... or any particular ethnic group because of the assumption that that ethnic group will provide mariachi music.

Michigan Department of State Police v. S.speaker: Justice Stevens
Michigan Department of State Police v. S.case_name: Michigan Department of State Police v. Sitz
Michigan Department of State Police v. S.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 27, 1990

context.speaker: Stephen L. Nightingale
context.text: If one were to prepare a list of the most important and serious threats to public health and safety in this country, drunk driving would have to be at or near the top of the list.

context.speaker: Stephen L. Nightingale
context.text: In 1988, 47,000 people were killed in traffic crashes in this country.

context.speaker: Stephen L. Nightingale
context.text: Of the roughly 62,000 drivers involved, 25 percent were intoxicated legally at the time of the accident.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Nightingale, going back to Justice O'Connor's question, is the problem any less serious with regard to firearms?

context.speaker: Stephen L. Nightingale
context.text: I believe that there were more people killed in traffic crashes, Your Honor, than there were in... by murder.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But only 25 percent of those are alcohol related, I thought you said.

Michigan Department of State Police v. S.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Michigan Department of State Police v. S.case_name: Michigan Department of State Police v. Sitz
Michigan Department of State Police v. S.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 27, 1990

context.speaker: Mark Granzotto
context.text: And in that sense, Mr. Justice White, we may have a situation where there is the... the end result of the court's decision in this case may be far more important to the law enforcement people in this country than any decision... any indication, let me say, that these sobriety roadblocks actually work in this country.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You want us to say this is unconstitutional if there's a more effective way of apprehending drug... drunk drivers?

context.speaker: Mark Granzotto
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That was precisely your answer to Justice Marshall, it seemed to me.

context.speaker: Mark Granzotto
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Mark Granzotto
context.text: It is not only... let me say it is not only that it is the less effective way, let me say, than... than roving patrols.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: But that's... when he said,

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: "But I don't know if I should talk to my lawyer. "

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: that pretty well told them, I think.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you think the case would be any different... I'm just thinking of Justice Kennedy's question... if the questioning had been by the prosecutor?

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: As to the Sixth Amendment I don't think it would make a difference, but I think we'd be into a different question in the State of Michigan as to the application of the ethical standards.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It would be clearly unethical, wouldn't it?

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: No, I'm saying a Jackson violation has occurred.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: What I am conceding in this case is that... that this was not an initiation by the defendant.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: And I'm conceding that simply because of the colloquy that occurred between the police officer and--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think you changed your position from your answer to Justice O'Connor which was that a constitutional violation occurred at the time of questioning.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: --Well, let me try to make it clear.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: The violation that occurred in this case occurred at the time of the questioning is what I'm now conceding to Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: And what I'm arguing to this Court today in the first portion of my argument is that Jackson establishes a prophylactic rule to protect waivers of counsel so that if an individual has asserted his right to counsel, you just can't question him at all.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: But I think that it is certainly conceivable and possible that if the police do initiate interrogation after the assertion of the right to counsel and we examined all the surrounding facts, that one could say as a matter of actual fact that a voluntary and intelligent and knowing waiver of the right to counsel has occurred.

context.speaker: Timothy A. Baughman
context.text: If that can occur, if it is possible to actually voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently waive the right to counsel, when the police initiate the interrogation, then the rule prohibiting that must be a prophylactic rule designed to protect, insure and enhance that guarantee, just as in the Edwards context it seeks to protect.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, what if, taking Justice Kennedy's example, the police had taken him up into the courtroom and set him on the witness stand with nobody there except the prosecutor and the police and said, we'd just like to ask you a few questions, and he says, I don't know whether I should or not, and, maybe I ought to talk to my lawyer.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Anyway, they go ahead and ask him the questions and he goes ahead and answers them.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He says, I will do it, maybe they want to see how he performs on the stand.

context.speaker: Robert M. Morgan
context.text: The notion that... contained in Jackson that in spite of full complete Miranda warnings, in spite of the fact that Jackson evidently made a voluntary statement, in spite of the fact that he made that statement knowingly, intelligently... a voluntary statement in compliance with Miranda... the court still held that because the right to counsel had attached that that waiver was not sufficient.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes, but the facts in Michigan against Jackson were that the police had initiated the thing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What I'm positing to you is totally initiated by the defendant.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Your position is like what Justice Frankfurter criticized in Adams against McCann.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You imprison the defendant in his rights.

context.speaker: Robert M. Morgan
context.text: Well, the defendant is always free to forgo the right to counsel.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, this....

context.speaker: Richard D. Panza
context.text: --Not because--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This man... this man was an educator.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I... I would think that Justice Scalia's hypothetical... if a statement like that had been made by an educator, I can hear some newspaper arguing that this is very, very relevant for social purposes.

context.speaker: Richard D. Panza
context.text: --Oh, and it absolutely is, if that's the scenario.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It... it would be all right?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Yeah.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Could I ask you another--

context.speaker: Richard D. Panza
context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Your response earlier to Justice Kennedy and me said that... the... suggested that the fact/opinion dichotomy only applies if it's a matter of... of public concern.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I... I hadn't understood your position to be that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought that the... and the courts that have applied that reasoning, I thought they apply it to all... all defamation actions, not just those that relate to matters of public concern.

context.speaker: Anne E. Peek
context.text: --I think if this case had occurred on the weekday that they would have done the same thing.

context.speaker: Anne E. Peek
context.text: They were faced with a murderer, someone who they felt was dangerous, someone who they felt was armed--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, that's the exigent circumstances.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But just on... on the right of the police to enter the dwelling, Justice O'Connor indicates that the rule you argue is fact specific, and I might add it's all post hoc.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You don't know about the key, and how long he's been there, and whether he has the right to exclude guests until after he is arrested and it comes out in suppression, so it's a very unworkable rule, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Anne E. Peek
context.text: --Well, presumptively, if the police are entering the home they want them to get a warrant, that's right, but if--

context.speaker: Anne E. Peek
context.text: --No, not necessarily.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, then, why is that different?

context.speaker: Anne E. Peek
context.text: Well, we're saying that... that Olson had basically nothing but legitimate--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Then you would have to answer Justice Scalia saying even if he were all alone he couldn't have said no.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Don't you have to look at it as though this person were the only person answering the door?

context.speaker: Anne E. Peek
context.text: --When you are in someone else's home, your right to exclude will always be subservient to the owner's--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Third, we affirm the judgment of the Minnesota Supreme Court in Minnesota against Olson.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Justices Stevens and Kennedy have filed concurring opinions, and the Chief Justice and Justice Blackmun have noted their dissent.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This by a five-to-four vote we affirm in part and reverse in part the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in Missouri against Jenkins, No. 88-1150.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment in which the Chief Justice and Justices O’Conner and Scalia have joined.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The case of Missouri versus Jenkins is a sufficient gravity that it seems appropriate for me to read from portions of the concurring opinion that has been filed today.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The case involves a school’s dissegregation plan adapted by United States District Court in Kansas City, Missouri.

National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin Matheson Scientific, Inc.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Shapiro, you said in your brief and you mentioned here as well, that the Board has decided, that the policy reasons for keeping the union in place are not dissipated by reason of the strike and replacement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: That may well be, but that's an evolution of its perception as to what the law should be, not an evolution of its perception as to what the facts are.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It seems to me that if the Board has that new policy perception it could abandon its... its current rule that the employer need not continue to recognize the union if he has a reasonable doubt.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Either adopt the procedure that Justice Kennedy was talking about or adopt some other procedure.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I don't see how the Board... the Board can prescribe facts.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It can prescribe law, but not facts.

National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin.speaker: Justice Scalia
National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin Matheson Scientific, Inc.
National Labor Relations Board v. Curtin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1989

context.speaker: James V. Carroll, III
context.text: And then we won't be concerned about whether we have denied one party or the other bargaining rights properly or improperly.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That would not serve the Board's policy of industrial peace, which it has decided is better served by leaving the current union in.

context.speaker: James V. Carroll, III
context.text: Well, I... first of all, I differ with that view as to what, whether that is a good policy, given that we have a new majority in the work force whose Section 7 rights should be taken into account, and they are not being taken into account under the Board's present rule, because the Board rules in all cases that replacement employees simply cannot be found to... doubt... to oppose the union, based on the way it is applying this rule.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Once again, Mr. Carroll, though, you... it seems to me you responded to Justice Stevens' question a little too categorically.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're not saying that it is automatic.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, you answered my question saying that if two years have gone by you would not apply the presumption.

context.speaker: Peter D. Coddington
context.text: --My second point is that Payton applies only to evidence seized in the house, and that evidence seized outside the house should not be suppressed under Payton.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That court held invalid certain regulations promulgated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, under which he nets or calculates the difference between past underpayments and past overpayments.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Some delay is inevitable to avoid errors and the Secretary’s regulations limit delay.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The respondent’s alternative suggestion would either increase the administrative burden or fail to remedy alleged delay problem.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Therefore, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with our opinion.

context.speaker: Kenneth V. Handal

context.speaker: Clifford M. Sloan
context.text: And that is why child support is in Title IV to begin with.

context.speaker: Clifford M. Sloan

context.text: This case is here from the Third Circuit, concerns supplemental security income benefits for children.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Social Security Act authorizes this for a child who suffers from an impairment of “comparable severity” to one that would render an adult disabled.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The District Court granted summary judgment for the Secretary.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Court of Appeals vacated that judgment for it found the regulatory scheme inconsistent with the Act.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed with the Clerk today, we agree that the child disability regulations are inconsistent with the statutory statement of comparable severity and we affirm the Court of Appeals judgment.

context.text: In an opinion filed with the Clerk, we reverse the judgment and remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We first conclude that petitioner, Committee on Legal Ethics, has standing and that respondent has third party standing to raise his client’s due process claims.
