context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In an opinion filed with the Clerk, we reverse the judgment and remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We first conclude that petitioner, Committee on Legal Ethics, has standing and that respondent has third party standing to raise his client’s due process claims.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: On the merits, we find that respondent has failed to prove that the scheme he challenges made attorneys unavailable to his prospective clients at the time he violated the Act.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a concurring opinion; Justice Marshall has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in part two of which Justice Brennan has joined; Justice Brennan has filed a separate statement.

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: I mean, the government would have to write her a check because it already had her money.

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: I was--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And perhaps... perhaps you think that you have been through this with Justice Stevens, but I want to make sure I understand it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Your position is that if she had filed a suit for a refund... I know she didn't, but suppose she had paid the income tax, filed the suit for a refund, would she have had a right... a right... to recoup the gift tax previously paid even though the gift tax... even though the statute of limitations had long since run?

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Yes, she would have had that right?

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: Yes, she would have.

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: And--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, what if... if in Justice Stevens' hypothetical instead of the income tax being $100,000 and the gift tax $30,000, the income tax is $100,000 and the gift tax $200,000, could she possibly have recovered more than $100,000 from the government?

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Christine Desan-husson
context.text: No.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 88-1951, United States against Dalm will be announced by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: United States versus Dalm is a tax case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In 1976 and 1977, the respondent, Frances Dalm, receives two payments from the estate of her deceased employer.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The doctrine maybe used to reconcile inconsistent taxes when one of the taxes is properly within the court’s jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But in this case, Dalm litigated her liability for income tax and then in a separate proceeding, attempted to litigate her equitable recoupment claim.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The doctrine of equitable recoupment cannot justify such a fragmented approach.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Brennan and Marshall join.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: "I am in opposition to this country? "

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: I think that assumes too much, with all respect.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: When Mr. Street burned the flag at issue in Street against New York, his stated concerns were with the failure to provide protection to James Meredith, who was not--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: General Starr, I wonder if, given Justice Scalia's interpretation of the obvious meaning of this conduct, maybe you should try to ban it on the grounds that it's misleading speech?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: --It may in say... in fact say too much, and more than the actor intended to convey, if in fact Justice Scalia is correct.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The reason that that type of activity is prohibited while the other examples that you mentioned are not is that in the Post... Postal Service's experience it was that direct solicitation, seeking an immediate act of charity on the spot, that led to the problems it experienced.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Do you think it's more bothersome than the leafletting?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I mean, is that demonstrable?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I... I think it is, Your Honor, and I think it follows from common sense, as Justice Blackmun noted in his separate opinion in the Heffron case.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: If you're walking down the street and you look ahead and see someone passing out leaflets, you know that you can take the leaflet and stick it in your pocket or read it later or toss in the nearest trash can.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: By the same token, picketing, which is permitted on postal property, if you look ahead and you see someone carrying a picket sign, you know that when you get there you can read the sign if you wish, react to it if you wish or just keep walking.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Most postal facilities do not have security forces, and it would be impossible to monitor compliance with the time, place and manner restrictions.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Finally, it concluded that such a system, which would leave considerable discretion with local postmasters either in... in implementation or enforcement, was undesirable given the far-flung nature of the commercial enterprise because they were concerned that the postmasters would discriminate on the basis of viewpoint or content.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, Mr. Roberts, I would assume that if the post offices are permitting petition gathering, signature gathering, that some of those could be conducted in a very aggressive manner, and very likely the Post Office is willing to have some kind of restrictions or regulations that it's willing to enforce to make sure that patrons aren't subjected to abusive tactics.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, it is true that, as I indicated in response to Justice Stevens' question, that petition gathering can have many of the same problems as... as solicitation; but given the Postal Service's experience, it wasn't creating serious problems.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: There was--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Does it have no reasonable time, place and manner restrictions on the picketing and the leafletting and the petition gathering?
Well, why isn't it overbroad for that reason?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --Because for the reason the Postal Service stated when it adopted these, is that it would be impossible to craft time, place and manner restrictions for every single one of the 35,000 post offices around the country; and, therefore--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, I suppose they could give the postmaster for each facility some authority to tailor the requirements to the configuration of that particular premises.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --A possibility, Your Honor, and one that they considered and expressly rejected because they did not want to have the postmasters having that discretion for, I think, largely the reason Justice Blackmun referred to.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The pressure on the postmaster to allow the Red Cross and the Girl Scouts to solicit--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Why couldn't you just say within 30 yards or 20 yards or 30 feet of any entrance?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The government is... is satisfied with the public forum doctrine as it's been established, which requires that the regulation--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, I didn't understand it that way.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --We'd be happy with... with one that didn't have... that we didn't have to give a reason at all, but certainly in this case the reasons that have been given by the Postal Service--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, but even in Justice Scalia's example, I suppose the reason is we own the property, and as a property owner we have control and so forth.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --That's right, and you can restrict as... as any business can access to the premises--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that changes the doctrine entirely.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: And here, there has not been this reservation of use.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: Rather, the Postal Service has invited the public in for postal services and nonpostal services, for the distribution of literature, for peaceful picketing, for petitioning for signatures.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: Yet they've singled out solicitation outside.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You said a moment ago in response to Justice O'Connor's question the post office could ban all of these things and say we're just running post office business here and all of you get out.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: Oh, they could ban it if in fact they operated as this quasi-military enclave, but they do not, Chief Justice.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, but I take it it would be permissible for them to do so, in your view?

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: And that is the difference.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: And that is the First Amendment mandates are to the state action sufficient--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It is not a difference for this argument.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You... you engaged in a discussion with... with Justice O'Connor, and Justice O'Connor said the mall outside is government owned but you're not allowed to go on it, and your argument was but the mall is not a sidewalk.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And this is a sidewalk.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Yes, it's set back from the street, but it's still a sidewalk.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Sekulow.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Roberts, you have two minutes remaining.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: First of all, Justice Blackmun, the cite for the authority to issue these regulations is 39 U.S.C., Section 401, subsection 2 in the Postal Service Act.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The distinction between the interior and the exterior is one that the Postal Service did not adopt in issuing these regulations.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Permitting solicitation on the outside carries many of the same administrative problems that would accompany permitting solicitation in the postal lobbies.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Anything else has to be irrational therefore?

context.speaker: John D. Seiver
context.text: --Well, not necessarily everything else has to be irrational, Justice Scalia, but if we look at it, at least we know when we go to court what we're in for.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But those are two different kinds of costs, the costs that are assessed now against losers in favor of winners are the out of pocket costs of the party.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What I think Justice Scalia's question is, these are the costs of operating the court system.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And you could say that the party assessment of costs could remain and still the assessment of the government's costs could be different, I would think.

context.speaker: John D. Seiver
context.text: Well, Your Honor, yes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's on your own assumption.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That is on your own assumption.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That you didn't really need the permission of the Mexican authorities.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think your answer to Justice O'Connor's question has to be yes, that if these people are living in a regime that lets people break into their houses and do anything they want, we should benefit from that regime as well as anybody else.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Isn't that your... isn't that essentially your position?

context.speaker: Lawrence S. Robbins
context.text: Well, I think there comes a point... and we've indicated that there is, as it were, a safety net to this argument provided by the Due Process Clause which operates in a very different way from the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: There is--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, what if a plaintiff--

context.speaker: Michael Pancer
context.text: --In a foreign country--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --What if a plaintiff brings a suit under 1983... the same hypothesis as Justice Kennedy's.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: No evidence was introduced to him but he's been the victim of a seizure of property that he says violates the Fourth Amendment because, as you say, the Fourth Amendment applies in that situation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: How does the court rule?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --And... and there would be a Federal cause of action.

context.speaker: George H. Cohen
context.text: And the Federal... it would be a Federal cause of action, but that would be the only cause of action for that kind of conduct, because what the union is trying to do in that circumstance is to influence the manner in which the employer is providing, is satisfying its relationship to that union.

context.speaker: George H. Cohen
context.text: Now, in most cases if there was a collective bargaining agreement, obviously that would be the union's purpose, to try to monitor the way the employer was living up to its commitments, and certainly to be in a position to try to influence the employer in the manner in which the employer was carrying out its responsibilities.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Cohen, take Justice Scalia's hypothetical a step further, if you will.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Supposing that the union officers... you don't need to look at the clock.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Suppose that the union officers were on their way to inspect the mine in a union-owned car ran over someone negligently.

context.text: Absolutely could sue via common law action.

context.speaker: George H. Cohen
context.text: It could, the duty of fair representation would play no role in that kind of a circumstance.

context.text: And precisely because the duty of fair representation would place no role, we aren't in a unique circumstance--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So, so if we were to conclude that the duty of fair representation really played no part in Justice Scalia's hypothetical, then that would mean that that... this... that action too would be... could be brought in state court?

context.speaker: George H. Cohen
context.text: --Yes, but I want to--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Your position is contrary, I realize that.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Would they assume a liability under Idaho law to the people who were later injured by an explosion?

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard
context.text: Justice Stevens, the Idaho law relating to this subject requires certain foundational elements be proved before you can determine whether somebody has established the necessary undertaking.

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard
context.text: It has to be an undertaking under either 323 or 324--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I am asking... I think Justice Scalia and I are both trying to find out what the source of the duty is.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And I thought your response was the source of the duty is the fact that they did in fact inspect.

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard
context.text: --That is correct.

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard
context.text: It... but--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: So, ultimately there is going to have to be some kind of duty established.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Otherwise, as Justice Stevens suggests, any volunteer going along on an inspection, a newspaper reporter, anybody, would become automatically liable.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: And you surely don't take that position.

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard
context.text: --Do not... we do not take that position, Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Isn't that the theory of the Idaho court, or is it?

context.speaker: Kenneth B. Howard

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: It is, rather, whether Congress intended to give the EEOC access to peer review materials.

context.speaker: Rex E. Lee
context.text: And on that particular issue, there is nothing in the statute that indicates that Congress even thought about the issue.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, Mr. Lee, despite your welcome assurances that this is a narrow issue, I just can't see it that way.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: As Justice O'Connor's first question indicated, what about the right of the press to hire the reporter that it wants or the editor that it wants, or the movie producer to hire the screen writer that it wants?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All of those are very, very close to protected First Amendment expression, core First Amendment expression.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And the Congress hasn't made any special rules for them either.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: At least, they did when I practiced.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: Well, Mr. Chief Justice, with all respect, this Court has said time and again, including a very instructive opinion by Justice Powell in Branzburg against Hays, noting that district courts do not have to blind themselves to the sensitivity, the potential sensitivity of litigation, and can govern the litigation appropriately.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: That is--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, Justice Powell's opinion was a one-person opinion in Branzburg.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: --Quite right.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: But I read it with great respect.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, Mr. Mosk, I thought you argued, with reference to the third question raised in your petition, that a Federal court in a civil rights case should not uphold a contingent fee agreement which is unenforceable under state law.

context.speaker: Richard M. Mosk
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: So I thought your argument was to the effect that the Federal court had to look to state law for enforceability.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Your responses to Justice White's questions indicate quite the reverse this morning.

context.speaker: Richard M. Mosk
context.text: Our position, Your Honor, is that, number one, as a matter of Federal law, the court should not enforce a contract... contingent fee contract where the lawyer has withdrawn prior to the advent of the contingency because that is a matter of general law.

context.speaker: Richard M. Mosk
context.text: Our next argument is that a Federal court should not bless or deem a contract to be reasonable if it violates state law, which it did here also.

context.speaker: Charles A. Miller
context.text: And he--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me your--

context.speaker: Charles A. Miller
context.text: --Not a windfall.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --answer to Justice O'Connor suggests that the damages really should have only been a million dollars.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Here we... he recovered $2 million.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think we have to assume that was the correct measure of his injury.

context.speaker: Edward Brodsky
context.text: The real important thing about the doctrine, when you get to the reason for it, is that the United States courts will be looking at in this case corruption at the highest level of the Government of Nigeria.

context.speaker: Edward Brodsky
context.text: That's what we're trying to prevent in this case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But our previous act of state doctrine cases don't point in that direction.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They don't suggest, as Justice Scalia said, that it would be embarrassing to a foreign government with whom we have friendly relations to have discovery about what went on in the award of the contract.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Therefore, the Court shouldn't hear it.

context.speaker: Edward Brodsky
context.text: Well, no, I think the case... I mean, the case that looks this way, in my opinion, is the Sabbatino case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 87-2066, Kirkpatrick and company versus Environmental Tectonics Corporation will be announced by Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This case is here on petition for certiorari to the Third Circuit.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The question it presents is whether the act of state doctrine bars the District Court from adjudicating a dispute between the parties.

context.speaker: Timothy K. Ford
context.text: But, again, to take the Court's hypothetical, there are always those facts that can be said to distinguish one homicide from another, to constitute as... cruelty because every homicide, as the Court has pointed out in Maynard, is... could be said by a reasonable person to be cruel.

context.speaker: Timothy K. Ford
context.text: You can always find a fact in any case that says, well, that's a cruel fact.

context.speaker: Timothy K. Ford
context.text: That's different than some other cases.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, what about this... how about the fact that Justice Scalia points to?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: You say it's a hypothetical but, nevertheless, that's what the... that's what the Arizona Supreme Court recited.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And what about that fact?

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But it's narrow enough without the cruel, heinous circumstance narrowing.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I... I thought I also understood your response to Justice Stevens that it does perform some narrowing function.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: That is also correct.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: It does it.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Then why... why is that question involved in this case?

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: The defendant makes a facial attack on the statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, I think we have to perhaps get back to what Justice O'Connor mentioned before.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: How... how do we get facial attacks on statutes where we're not talking about the First Amendment?

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: Because the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals held that our statute was unconstitutional on its face in that... in that case.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: And the judge said, I believe... I believe you did beyond a reasonable doubt.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: So, it was relevant in that he rejected one of the proffered mitigating circumstances asked by defendant.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: But it did not go to the aggravation in any form.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And... and how do you distinguish this from Justice Stevens' hypothetical in his separate opinion in which he said that it's like an assault and then the further inquiries whether it's assault with intent to kill or assault within the course of a rape?

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: The elements of whether or not the defendant is liable for first-degree murder have not changed.

context.speaker: Paul Joseph McMurdie
context.text: There... they're still there.

context.speaker: William L. Williams
context.text: That's what he says, your Honor, but that's not true.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Uh-huh.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I gather--

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: --What I have just represented to Justice O'Connor is not in the record because the record closed when the trial took place in 1987.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, but I gather the state's position was that in any event he had been involuntarily medicated between April '87 and May '88.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Is that right?

context.speaker: Brian Reed Phillips
context.text: I want to emphasize the importance of this liberty interest.

context.speaker: Brian Reed Phillips
context.text: I think that the First Amendment is implicated here.

context.speaker: Brian Reed Phillips
context.text: It was... that claim by the respondent was not addressed by the lower court, but I think it is an important consideration in deciding how important this liberty interest is and how important the private interest is, because if one cannot generate ideas or if one's ability to generate ideas is affected by mind-altering drugs, then the ability to express those ideas is going to be similarly affected.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, as an original proposition I think that's... that's very appealing, and I might agree with it, that maybe the state shouldn't have the right to alter anybody's mind without the person's consent unless the person is incompetent in the sense that Justice O'Connor was speaking of.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But in fact do you have any idea whether that has been... been the tradition in this country in either... in either penal institutions or mental institutions?

context.speaker: Brian Reed Phillips
context.text: The tradition of--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 88-599, Washington against Harper will be announced by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This case is before us on certiorari to the Supreme Court of the State of Washington.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It is Washington versus Harper.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The decision is made after a full hearing with the prisoner having a knowledgeable person to assist him in presenting any objections.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The decision to be made here is medical in nature, not judicial.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Our precedents recognized that in such cases, the state can reasonably decide that medical professionals, not judges, are the most appropriate decision makers.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, as a standard reason, the failure to obey the subpoena.

context.speaker: Kenneth A. Payment
context.text: --I'm sure that that was their position.

context.speaker: Kenneth A. Payment
context.text: The subpoena... the summons had not been obeyed, and therefore, as sort of a punitive measure, the entire deduction was disallowed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm... I'm still not sure how you answered Justice Stevens' question that I was interested in.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Which is, suppose the IRS just says we're going to have a... a routine audit of every hundredth return.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And we're going to go into it from top to bottom.

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: "It is no basis for refusing to enforce a summons to say that the Service ought to be focusing on something else. "

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: And I suppose there are a lot of taxpayers out there who, let's say, take liberties with certain small items on their return because they think the Service has got more important things to do.

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: But I think that's a lot of gall to turn that, I guess, attempt to get away with something into a right to actually challenge the service, when the service does happen to look into one of these smaller matters.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Is your next step along the line of Justice O'Connor's question?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Are you going to question claims that have been allowed in every probate in New York?

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: There is no next step, Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: The idea is to make an inquiry into state law.

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: The reasons for that rule are explained by the court in Bosch, and there is no reason to have a different rule for this particular estate deduction than there is for the marital deduction that was at issue there.

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: We don't think the taxpayer has any--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But you certainly can say there is a reason, suggested by Justice Stevens' question that, in Bosch, there was a motive on the part of all the parties to the litigation to have it come out a particular way, in order to reduce their tax liability.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Here there is a motive on the part of the beneficiaries not to want to pay any larger estate attorney's fee or executor's commission than was required by law.

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: [inaudible]

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I have the opinion of the Court to announce in No. 88-928, James White versus the United States.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The writ of certiorari has dismissed as improvidently granted.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice White Dissents.

context.text: That isn't--

context.speaker: J. Steven Clark
context.text: --Oh, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: --It's on the standing argument.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Take Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Here is a public defender that represented him all up and down the line in the... in the proceedings and he shows up at the prison and he finds out that the fellow is in a dungeon and they won't let... and they won't let him talk to him.

context.speaker: J. Steven Clark
context.text: Well,--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: He has not sustained injury in fact sufficient to establish an Article III case or controversy, because any harm to Whitmore caused by Simmons' failure to appeal is purely speculative, nor we hold that Whitmore have standing to proceed as what is called the "next friend" of Simmons.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Standing in that capacity is not available whereas here, an evidentiary hearing shows that the defendant has given a knowing, intelligent, involuntary waiver of his right to proceed and has access to court as otherwise impaired.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The writ of certiorari is therefore dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That language specifies that a state Medicaid plan must provide for the payment of rates which the state finds, and makes assurances satisfactory to the Secretary, are reasonable and adequate to meet the costs that an efficiently and economically operated facility must incur to provide care and services and to assure that eligible individuals have reasonable access to services of adequate quality.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In providing for state findings and assurances, this language vests responsibility for rate setting squarely on the shoulders of the states.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It does not secure any substantive Federal right to the payment of particular rates.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Roberts, can I just interrupt to ask you the same question that Justice O'Connor asked earlier of your colleague?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: What was... what is your view of the situation before the Boren Amendment?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Was there a cause of action under 1983 then?

context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 89-431, Yellow Freight System, Inc. verus Donnelly will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: This case comes to us on a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Respondent filed a complaint in a State Court, the Circuit Court of Cook County, alleging that the petitioner had discriminated against her because she is a woman in violation of the Illinois Human Rights Act and also Title VII of the Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 87-1965 Zinermon against Burch will be announced by Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, this case coming to us from the Eleventh Circuit concern so-called voluntary admissions to a Florida state mental hospital.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In a sense, it is related to the Washington against Harper decision announced this morning by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 87-1965 Zinermon against Burch will be announced by Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, this case coming to us from the Eleventh Circuit concern so-called voluntary admissions to a Florida state mental hospital.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In a sense, it is related to the Washington against Harper decision announced this morning by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The respondent signed forms requesting the admission and treatment at the hospital, and this was an apparent compliance with state statutes, but after his release he brought this action under 1983, a federal statute, against petitioners who were physicians and staff members of the hospital on the ground that they had deprived him of his liberty without due process of law.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The complaint alleged that they violated state law by admitting Burch as a voluntary patient when they knew or should have known that he was incompetent to give informed consent and that their failure to initiate Florida’s involuntary placement procedure denied him constitutionally guaranteed procedural safeguards.
